title: Dasylirion wheeleri
text:
Dasylirion wheeleri (desert spoon, spoon flower, sotol, or common sotol) is a <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a> in the asparagus family Asparagaceae, native to arid environments of northern Mexico, in Chihuahua and Sonora and in the southwestern United States, in the Sonoran Desert in Arizona, and also in New Mexico and Texas.
Etymology.
"Dasylirion" is a compound word from the Greek, literally meaning “dense” or “shaggy” + “lily”. The Latin <a href="binomial%20nomenclature">specific epithet</a> "wheeleri" refers to the American surveyor and plant collector <a href="George%20Montague%20Wheeler">George Montague Wheeler</a> (1842-1905).
Description.
"Dasylirion wheeleri" is a moderate to slow-growing <a href="evergreen">evergreen</a> <a href="shrub">shrub</a> with a single unbranched trunk up to thick growing to tall, though often recumbent on the ground. The <a href="leaf">leaf</a> blade is slender, 35–100 cm long, gray-green, with a toothed margin. The leaves radiate from the center of the plant's apex in all directions (spherical).
The <a href="flower">flower</a>ing stem grows above the foliage, to a height of tall, and 3 cm in diameter. The stem is topped by a long plume of straw-colored small flowers about 2.5 cm long with six <a href="tepal">tepal</a>s. The color of the flower determinate the gender of the plant, being mostly white colored for males and purple-pink for females. The <a href="fruit">fruit</a> is an oval dry <a href="capsule%20%28fruit%29">capsule</a> 5–8 mm long, containing a single <a href="seed">seed</a>.
Cultivation and uses.
"D. wheeleri" is grown as an <a href="ornamental%20plant">ornamental plant</a>, valued in <a href="xeriscaping">xeriscaping</a>. As it does not tolerate extended frosts, in <a href="temperateness">temperate</a> regions it is usually grown under glass. It has gained the <a href="Royal%20Horticultural%20Society">Royal Horticultural Society</a>'s <a href="Award%20of%20Garden%20Merit">Award of Garden Merit</a>.
The alcoholic drink <a href="sotol">sotol</a>, the northern cousin to <a href="tequila">tequila</a> and <a href="mezcal">mezcal</a>, is made from the fermented inner cores of the desert spoon. It is the state drink of the Mexican states of <a href="Chihuahua%20%28state%29">Chihuahua</a>, <a href="Durango">Durango</a>, and <a href="Coahuila">Coahuila</a>.
It was also used by the natives of the region for food and fiber. Its flower stalk can be used as a <a href="Fire%20making%23Fire%20Plow">fire plow</a>.
The <a href="Tarahumara">Tarahumara</a> and <a href="Pima%20Bajo%20people">Pima Bajo</a> peoples of the <a href="Sierra%20Madre%20Occidental">Sierra Madre Occidental</a> of <a href="Chihuahua%20%28state%29">Chihuahua</a> weave baskets from the leaves after they strip off the spines from the leaf margins. They also employ the expanded leaf bases in making large artificial flowers as holiday decorations.
